result.execSummary:
The defendant Thomas R Fisher Jr was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).
  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).
  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Thomas R Fisher Jr

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Defendant Thomas R Fisher in court with attorney David R. Dickmann.  Craig Lambert appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Plea hearing on October 6, 2014 at 10:00 am.
Jury trial - 12 person on November 4, 2014 at 08:30 am.
Jury trial - 12 person on August 13, 2014 at 08:30 am.
2:47 Defendant Thomas R Fisher in court with attorney David R Dickmann.  Derek Dominguez appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Not guilty pleas entered.  Bond continued

2:47 Defendant Thomas R Fisher in court with attorney David R Dickmann.  Derek Dominguez appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  

Jared Beauchamp is sworn as a witness.  Testifies to his employment with Marshfield Pd.  Testifies to contact with Michael Atkin with Payday Loan, regarding phone calls made to collection center regarding a bomb in the building.  Testifies to location of Payday Loan Building in Marshfield.  Phone calls were made to call center in Texas.  Testifies to the nature of the phone calls and to the employee of Payday asking if the caller was Thomas Fisher and to the employee seeing on caller ID who the caller was.  Testifies to Fisher's connection to Payday Loan and to amount of loan Fisher owes with Payday Loan.  Testifies to listening to recorded conversations.  Phone calls took place on 05/20/14 and that is the day he spoke with Fisher.  Testifies to what Payday Loan did internally regarding the bomb scares.  Calls were traced back to Shelly Fisher phone.  Shelly Fisher is the wife of Thomas.  Testifies to contact with manager of Marshfield Payday Loan and to clearing the building for explosives.  No explosives were found.  Office Punke spoke with Shelly Fisher and to comment she made regarding Thomas being the only one to use the phone on that day in the morning.  Identifies Thomas Fisher Jr in the courtroom.  Testifies to comparing voice in recording to that of Thomas Fisher Jr and believing it was Thomas.  Law enforcement reported to Fisher residence within 15 mins of receiving complaint.

Atty Dickmann cross examines the witness.  Testifies to where the 2 bomb scare calls went too.  Did not identify person that received either call.  Defines a reverse trace.  Identifies the manager of the Marshfield Payday Loan store.  Testifies to when calls were made.  Testifies to meeting with Fisher on several prior occasions.  Testifies to the length of recordings.

Court finds probable cause and binds the matter over for Arraignment.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for July 18, 2014 at 10:00 am.
No contact with EZ Money Payday Loans.
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment on June 3, 2014 at 02:45 pm.
No contact with EZ Money Payday Loans
Defendant Thomas R Fisher in court with attorney Emily M Nolan-Plutchak.  Defendant Thomas R Fisher in custody.  Derek Dominguez appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
